The kits convert the fittings to use energy efficient, high frequency ballasts and accommodate the smaller diameter T5 lamp.<ref name="ct" />
The magnetic ballast remains in place but it is bypassed, rendering it ineffective as a conductor. The new high-frequency ballast draws only 2 [[Watt|W]], rather than the 6-10 W of the old ballast, increasing the efficiency of the system.<ref name="bsd">{{Cite web|title=New generation energy efficient fluorescent tubes: triphosphor|url=http://www.bsdlive.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=3110142|publisher=Building Sustainable Design|accessdate=2009-11-30}}</ref> Changing to this type of lamp without taking the ballast out of operation (rather than simply bypassing it) results in an increased power factor for the fitting. This increase in power is a result of the separate coils used in an electric ballast, as opposed to the single coil in a magnetic ballast, because it allows the electricity to flow more consistently.<ref>http://www.thegrowlightdistrict.com/2015/08/t5-vs-t8/</ref>
There are tree main types of conversion kits: * '''Lamp-end type''' – Kits which include a replacement starter and two separate components to fit over each end of the T5 lamp. The lamp is then slotted into the existing fitting. * '''Baton type''' – One piece kits which slot into the existing fitting and into which the T5 lamp is placed.<ref name="ct" /> * '''IP65 types''' – Waterproof [http://store.elam-lighting.eu/en/t5-retrofit-energy-save IP65 T5-module]
==Energy efficiency== T5 retrofit conversion can maintain existing lighting levels at up to 65% reduction in energy use.<ref name="sie" />
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.bsdlive.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=3110142 Building Sustainable Design - New generation energy efficient fluorescent tubes: triphosphor]
[[Category:Light fixtures]] [[Category:Environmental engineering]]

The '''Hartwell Paper''' called for a reorientation of [[climate policy]] after the perceived failure in [[2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference|2009 of the UNFCCC climate conference in Copenhagen]]. It was a response to the [[United Nations]]' [[Kyoto Protocol]], a previous international agreement meant to reduce [[greenhouse gas]] emissions. The paper was published in May 2010 by the [[London School of Economics]] in cooperation with the [[University of Oxford]]. The authors are 14 natural and social scientists from Asia, Europe and North America, including [[Mike Hulme]], [[Roger A. Pielke (Jr)]], [[Nico Stehr]] and [[Steve Rayner]], who met under the [[Chatham House Rule]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://eprints.lse.ac.uk/27939/1/HartwellPaper_English_version.pdf|title=The Hartwell Paper|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
The authors saw the [[Great Recession|2009 economic crisis]] as an opportunity to re-evaluate global priorities. They argued that "decarbonisation will only be achieved successfully as a benefit contingent upon other goals which are politically attractive and relentlessly pragmatic."
[[File:Hartwell House, Bucks.jpg| thumb | right | 200px | [[Hartwell House, Buckinghamshire|Hartwell House]], where the meetings took place.]]
They emphasize [[human dignity]] as a necessary guiding principle for climate [[Climate policy|policy]]: "To reframe the climate issue around matters of human dignity is not just noble or necessary. It is also likely to be more effective than the approach of framing around human sinfulness – which has failed and will continue to fail."<ref>[http://www.europeanbusinessreview.com/?p=2303 EU Climate Policy after the Crash of 09.] The European Business Review, September 2010 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325063036/http://www.europeanbusinessreview.com/?p=2303 |date=25 March 2014 }}</ref>
This principle of human dignity is expanded to three main objectives: * 1. Energy access for all - the paper advocates taking investments in the innovations of renewable energy to decrease energy costs and to make them more affordable to society. Only this diversification of energy could extend the access to energy, especially in undeveloped countries.<ref name=":0" />
* 2. Development that does not interfere with essential Earth systems. * 3. Societies well equipped to withstand climate-related dangers.
Their ultimate goal is "to develop non-carbon energy supplies at unsubsidised costs less than those using [[fossil fuels]]."<ref name=":0">[http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/mackinderProgramme/theHartwellPaper The Hartwell Paper.] [[London School of Economics]], May 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.economist.com/world/international/displayStory.cfm?story_id=16099521 Oblique strategies], [[The Economist]], 11 May 2010</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8673828.stm After the crash - a new direction for climate policy.] BBC News, 11 May 2010</ref>
The Hartwell Paper recommends that they are to achieve this goal by introducing low [[carbon]] [[Carbon tax|taxes]]. However, this money is able to be used to develop a CO2 free energy supply.<ref name=":0" />
== Kyoto and Climate Change Misconceptions ==
"The previous 'Kyoto' model has dangerously narrowed the option space for thinking seriously and realistically about energy and environmental policies. The Hartwell Paper wishes to contribute to a new pragmatism in the policy discourse surrounding climate change. To this end, we gathered at Hartwell House in Buckinghamshire in February 2010 and this paper is the base of our work".
The Hartwell Paper argues that, although we should attempt to reduce climate change, we must also prepare to adapt if necessary. According to the authors, the Kyoto principles implied that adaptation to the environment should be seen as a failure to halt climate change. Those at the Hartwell meeting proposed that these strategies; mitigation, and adaptation, should both be employed. This is to keep in mind the dignity of those who would be most affected while simultaneously slowing global warming.
The following are climate myths presented in the paper: * '''Climate change is a problem that must be solved''' - "Rather than being a discrete problem to be solved. Climate change is better understood as a persistent condition that must be coped with and can only be partially managed more – or less – well. It is just one part of a larger complex of such conditions encompassing population, technology, wealth disparities, resource use, etc."<ref name=":1" />
* '''The "deficit model" of science''' - The idea that the lack of information hinders the making of environmental progress. Once the science is understood by all, an agreement can be reached. The Hartwell authors call this a myth, saying that it doesn't address the varying political and religious ideologies that can result in differing interpretations of scientific data. "In turn, this error has led to the common and flawed assumption that the solutions to climate change should be ‘science driven’ as if a shared understanding of science will lead to a political consensus."<ref name=":1" />
== Key Features of Hartwell Plan ==
The authors propose a holistic model of environmental practice. They believe there has been too much emphasis placed on carbon dioxide as if it is our only problematic emission. They state that while the CO2 reduction is central to the plan, smaller changes in a variety of practices and industries are also important. * Diversification and moving away from fossil fuels * Eradication of "Black Carbon" - Black Carbon is simply soot, which can come from burning wood or coal within the home. This has an environmental effect far greater (per ton) than simple CO2. According to the authors, this is an important step to take, as it should be much easier than phasing out gasoline. * Reduce Tropospheric Ozone * Protect Tropical Forests * The "Kaya Identity" - these are four primary factors when it comes to a region's environmental footprint. They are population, wealth, energy intensity, and carbon intensity. Nations face different environmental issues, and the solution for one is not the solution for all.
== Reception and Criticism ==
The Hartwell Paper has received both praise and criticism. According to The Economist, the Hartwell approach to decarbonisation has been a source of controversy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/16099521|title=Oblique strategies|date=2010-05-11|work=The Economist|access-date=2017-12-04|issn=0013-0613}}</ref> Because large, rapidly industrializing nations are driven by fossil fuels, the authors claim that slowing this process just isn't politically feasible. ''The Economist'' article argues that Hartwell's "oblique strategies" may be more difficult to turn into policy than a more direct attack on carbon dioxide emissions.

{{Use American English|date=December 2012}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox book | name = The War for Late Night | image = warforlatenightcover.jpg | caption = Book cover |alt=A blue book cover with its title written in yellow lettering. A television showing Conan O'Brien pointing a finger at Jay Leno is squeezed between the title's words in the center. | author = Bill Carter | country = United States | language = English | publisher = [[Viking Press|Viking]] | release_date = November 4, 2010 | english_release_date = | media_type = Hardcover | pages = 384 | isbn = 978-0-670-02208-3 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = [[The Late Shift (book)|The Late Shift]] }} '''''The War for Late Night: When Leno Went Early and Television Went Crazy''''' is a 2010 [[non-fiction]] book written by ''[[The New York Times]]'' media reporter Bill Carter. It chronicles the [[2010 Tonight Show conflict|2010 conflict]] surrounding the American late-night talk show ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' involving [[Conan O'Brien]] and [[Jay Leno]]. It is a sequel to Carter's 1994 book ''[[The Late Shift (book)|The Late Shift]]'', which detailed the struggle for the hosting spot on ''The Tonight Show'' between [[David Letterman]] and [[Jay Leno]] in the early 1990s following the retirement of [[Johnny Carson]]. It was first published on November 4, 2010, by [[Viking Press]].
The book received a generally favorable reception from reviewers including ''[[Associated Press]]'', ''[[BusinessWeek]]'', ''[[The Buffalo News]]'', ''[[New York Magazine]]'', ''[[Star Tribune]]'', ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', ''[[New York Post]]'', ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', and [[ABC News]]. The ''[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]'' said, "''The War for Late Night'' ... offers an exhaustive, eye-opening, how-could-he-possibly-know-that look at the late-night feud that ultimately was a muddled victory for Leno: He won back ''The Tonight Show'', but his ratings have fallen below O'Brien's."<ref name="christopherlawrence" />
==Background== Author Bill Carter previously wrote ''[[The Late Shift (book)|The Late Shift]]'', a book about the 1992 conflict between Jay Leno and David Letterman to decide who would succeed [[Johnny Carson]] as host of ''[[The Tonight Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20101107/LIFE/11070318/-1/NEWSMAP|accessdate=2010-11-08|date=November 7, 2010|title=Conan O'Brien's big night|work=Cape Cod Times|publisher=www.capecodonline.com|last=Hartlaub|first=Peter}}</ref> The book was well received by critics from publications including ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'',<ref name="katz">{{cite journal|last =Katz| first=Jon|title=The Late Shift|journal=[[The New York Times Book Review]]|volume=99|page=11|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]| date =February 20, 1994 }}</ref> and ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''.<ref name="campbell">{{cite journal|last =Campbell| first=Kim|title=The Late Shift|journal=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] (Eastern edition)|page=17| date = March 11, 1994 }}</ref>
==Research== Carter researched for the book during 2010.<ref>{{cite news| last = Sassone | first = Bob | title =New 'Late Shift' Book in the Works | work =TV Squad | publisher = www.tvsquad.com| date = February 11, 2010 | url =http://www.tvsquad.com/2010/02/11/new-late-shift-book-in-the-works/ | accessdate =2010-10-04 }}</ref> He had secured a publishing deal for the book by January of that year.<ref>{{cite news| last = Gray| first = Ellen | title =Conan ready to walk | work = [[Philadelphia Daily News]] | date =January 13, 2010 }}</ref> Carter confirmed to Gillian Reagan of ''[[Business Insider]]'' that in his research, he tried to gather information from multiple viewpoints. He said, "I'm reaching out to everyone I possibly can to get every side of the story."<ref name="gillianreagan">{{cite news| url= http://www.businessinsider.com/bill-carters-new-book-will-focus-on-conan-obrien-jay-leno-debacle-2010-2| title= Bill Carter's New Book Will Focus On Conan O'Brien-Jay Leno Debacle|first=Gillian |last=Reagan | work=[[Business Insider]]| date= February 11, 2010|publisher=Business Insider, Inc.|accessdate=2010-10-04}} [http://gawker.com/5469767/new-york-times-bill-carter-at-work-on-a-late-shift-sequel alternate link]</ref> Carter said that he was remaining neutral about the 2010 ''Tonight Show'' conflict. "I obviously have to reach out to all sides", he said. "For the longest time, I personally tried to watch as many episodes of all the shows as I could to get sense of each show, and what each guy does. I don't just pick one and stick with that guy."<ref name="gillianreagan" /> Carter researched the impact of financial decision-making on the controversy.<ref name="juliemiller" /> He said he had known Leno for a long time, and O'Brien since he began working for NBC, and that these connections gave him the benefit of familiarity.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.expressnightout.com/2010/11/bill-carter-the-war-for-late-night/|accessdate=2010-11-09|date=November 8, 2010|title=All's Fair in Love and TV: Bill Carter, 'The War for Late Night'|work=Express Night Out|publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]]}}</ref>
==Contents== ''The War for Late Night'' chronicles the 2010 conflict surrounding the American late-night talk show ''The Tonight Show'' involving [[Conan O'Brien]] and [[Jay Leno]].<ref name="bershad">{{cite news|last=Bershad|first=Jon|title=Bill Carter’s The War for Late Night Excerpt Is As Tense And Entertaining As Expected|work=Mediaite|publisher=Mediaite, LLC|date=October 28, 2010|url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/the-war-for-late-night-excerpt/|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> Carter gives biographical description of other late-night television personalities, including [[David Letterman]], [[Jimmy Fallon]], [[Jimmy Kimmel]], [[Craig Ferguson]], [[Jon Stewart]] and [[Stephen Colbert]].<ref name="jayvsconan">{{cite news|title=Jay Vs. Conan: Late-Night Warriors in a New Book|work=[[ABC News]]|last=Moore|first=Frazier ([[Associated Press]])|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]|date=November 2, 2010}} [http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/articles/2010/11/02/jay_vs_conan_late_night_warriors_in_a_new_book/ alternate link].</ref> As host of ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', O'Brien decided to remain with NBC after attempts by [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] and [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] to attract him to their networks{{emdash}}as NBC executives had told O'Brien that he would become host of ''The Tonight Show'' after Leno's retirement.<ref name="duanedudek">{{cite news|first=Duane|last=Dudek|title=Conan O'Brien gets new shot at chasing Carson's mantle|url=http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/tvradio/106860428.html|accessdate=2010-11-08|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date=November 7, 2010}}</ref> While hosting ''The Tonight Show'' and analyzing ratings results, O'Brien told his manager [[Gavin Polone]] that he feared that Leno might be moved back to the program.<ref name="stableford">{{cite news|last=Stableford|first=Dylan|work=TheWrap|title='Conan' to Launch With Online Show a Week Before TV Debut|date=October 28, 2010|publisher=The Wrap News Inc|url=http://www.thewrap.com/media/column-post/tbs-launch-conan-show-zero-online-week-ahead-tv-debut-22046|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> Carter's book contains details of O'Brien's and Leno's contracts, and describes O'Brien's emotional state during the 2010 conflict.<ref name="paskin">{{cite news|work=[[New York Magazine]]|title=The Best Quotes From Behind-the-Scenes of the Conan-Leno War|date=October 28, 2010|first=Willa |last=Paskin|publisher= New York Media LLC|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2010/10/conan_vs_leno_the_quotes.html|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> According to Carter, Leno had an advantage during negotiations because of a stronger contract agreement with NBC,<ref name="natejones">{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Nate|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]|date=October 28, 2010|title=Late Night Wars, Exposed: New Book Reveals Why Conan Lost, How NBC Fawned Over Leno|publisher=Time Inc|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2010/10/28/the-late-night-war-of-2010-gets-its-first-official-history/|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> which gave Leno the option to sue NBC if his program was canceled.<ref name="joelkeller">{{cite news|first=Joel|last=Keller|work=TV Squad|title=Leno Had NBC Over a Legal Barrel, Says Bill Carter's New Book|date=October 28, 2010|publisher=AOL Inc|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2010/10/28/leno-had-nbc-over-a-legal-barrel-says-bill-carters-new-book/|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref>
NBC executives tried to solve the problem so that both Leno and O'Brien would keep their jobs.<ref name="nealjustin" /> [[Jeff Gaspin]], the chairman of [[NBC Universal Television]], instructed both parties that he did not wish to make a difficult decision but that the most appropriate solution was to move Leno back to his previous timeslot and push O'Brien to 12:05.<ref name="jackmirkinson">{{cite news|first=Jack|last=Mirkinson|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=October 28, 2010|title=Conan Vs. Jay: The Best Bits From Bill Carter's Book On O'Brien-Leno Fiasco|publisher=HuffingtonPost.com, Inc.|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/28/conan-vs-jay-bill-carter_n_775591.html|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> Carter details a heated exchange between NBC executive [[Jeff Zucker]] and O'Brien's agent Rick Rosen during which Zucker told O'Brien's representatives he could enforce O'Brien's contract and "ice him for two years", after details of the conflict were leaked to the media.<ref name="pauladuffy">{{cite news|last=Duffy|first=Paula|title=Leno vs. Conan TV Wars, Hot Details in Bill Carter's New Book|work=HULIQ News|publisher=Huliq.com|date=October 29, 2010|url=http://www.huliq.com/10061/leno-vsconan-tv-wars-hot-details-bill-carters-new-book|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> The author cites O'Brien's disappointment with the perceived unfairness of the situation, and quotes O'Brien's comments at a meeting with [[NBC Universal|NBC Entertainment]] and [[Universal Media Studios]] chairman Marc Graboff and Jeff Gaspin, "I know how hard I worked for this. It was promised to me. I had a shitty lead-in."<ref name="thrjeffzucker">{{cite news|author=THR Staff|title=Bill Carter's book reveals explosive new details about the Jay Leno-O'Brien debacle.|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 29, 2010|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jeff-zucker-conan-obriens-agent-33615|accessdate=2010-10-29}}</ref> Carter recounts how affiliates of NBC complained to the network about the poor ratings performance of Leno's program ''[[The Jay Leno Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news|date=November 6, 2010|title=Why Conan will have NBC seeing red|work=[[Kansas City Star]]|first= Aaron |last=Barnhart}}</ref> O'Brien asked the two NBC executives, "What does Jay have on you? What does this guy have on you people? What the hell is it about Jay?"<ref name="thrjeffzucker" /><ref name="storylab">{{cite news|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]]|date=November 2, 2010|title=Pick of the day: The ballad of Jay and Conan|first=Paul|last=Schwartzman|url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/story-lab/2010/11/pick_of_the_day_the_ballad_of.html|accessdate=2010-01-02}}</ref>
Carter writes about how the "Team Coco" movement and fans impacted O'Brien following the controversy, "The outpouring of support made Conan feel as if he was starring in his own version of the movie ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'', both because he was allowed to see a 'Tonight Show' where he never existed and because the support made him realize he really was 'the richest man in town.'"<ref name="marikar" /> O'Brien was hurt by the fact that Leno did not communicate directly with him during the fiasco.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6A40AU20101105|accessdate=2010-11-08|work=[[Reuters]]|publisher=www.reuters.com|date=November 4, 2010|title=Conan won't invite Jay on new show, except to sing}}</ref> Carter also says that compared to the eventual payout to O'Brien of $45 million, NBC would have suffered a financial loss of $235 million if O'Brien had left the company in 2004 to host a talk show for another network.<ref name="windolf" /> O'Brien moved from NBC to host his own late night program on [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Carter|first=Bill|work=[[Good Morning America]]|title=Excerpt: 'The War for Late Night' By Bill Carter|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=November 8, 2010|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Books/gma-book-excerpt-war-late-night-bill-carter/story?id=12066165|accessdate=2010-11-08}}</ref> Carter's work concludes with an interview from comic [[Jerry Seinfeld]], who favored Leno; Seinfeld argues that O'Brien should have remained at NBC.<ref name="ricenov4">{{cite news|last=Rice|first=Lynette|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=November 3, 2010|title=Book Review, The War for Late Night (2010), Bill Carter|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20439043,00.html|accessdate=2010-11-04}}</ref>
==Reception==
Writing for ''[[New York Post]]'', Larry Getlen wrote, "Veteran journalist Bill Carter details the vicious recent battle over ''The Tonight Show'', showing how Leno was hardly the devious schemer he was made out to be, and how O’Brien was not always the angelic innocent the media portrayed, as he and his team aggressively pursued the show at every opportunity."<ref name="getlen">{{cite news|work=[[New York Post]]|first=Larry|last=Getlen|title=The war for late night: In ‘Tonight Show’ battle, Leno wasn’t always the bad guy|date=October 16, 2010|publisher=NYP Holdings, Inc|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/opinion/books/the_war_for_late_night_Kd9hc34c5RgPMmdiXOWTRL|accessdate=2010-10-26}}</ref> Jon Bershad of ''[[Mediaite]]'' commented, "It’s as tense and exciting as expected."<ref name="bershad" /> Writing for ''[[TV Squad]]'', Joel Keller analyzed Carter's comparison of Leno's legal contract with O'Brien's, and wrote that the author "paints a picture of Leno and his producer, Debbie Vickers, as pragmatists and Conan as a cockeyed idealist".<ref name="joelkeller" /> Joe Flint of ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' commented about changes in the media industry since Carter's prior book ''The Late Shift'', "The only difference is that the media world has changed a lot then, and while ''The Late Shift'' had a lot of inside dirt and drama that was news to everyone but the most hardcore industry insiders, this time around the soap opera played out on TV and in the media."<ref>{{cite news|last=Flint|first=Joe|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2010/10/the-morning-fix-meg-whitman-and-jerry-brown-pour-it-on-lions-gate-sues-carl-icahn-redbox-wants-to-get-its-kiosks-onto-the-web.html|accessdate=2010-10-30|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=The Morning Fix: Can't remember what happened 10 months ago in late night?|date=October 29, 2010}}</ref> James Poniewozik of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' wrote, "There are lots of juicy bits, but the big takeaway: the guy with the best contract, wins",<ref>{{cite news|first=James|last=Poniewozik|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]|title=Weekend Reading: How Jay Beat Conan (and NBC)|date=October 29, 2010|accessdate=2010-10-30|url=http://tunedin.blogs.time.com/2010/10/29/weekend-reading-how-jay-beat-conan-and-nbc/}}</ref> and called the book, "Bill Carter's Jaypocalypse dirt-disher".<ref>{{cite news|first=James|last=Poniewozik|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time magazine]]|title=Letterman Defeats Leno! Stewart Defeats Both!|accessdate=2010-11-08|url=http://tunedin.blogs.time.com/2010/11/05/letterman-defeats-leno-stewart-defeats-both/|date=November 5, 2010}}</ref> Writing for ''[[ABC News]]'', journalist Sheila Marikar commented, "Bill Carter's new book, 'The War for Late Night,' reveals what happened behind the scenes, the expletives that were hurled during closed-door discussions, the roller coaster that O'Brien, Leno, and their cohorts rode during that tumultuous time."<ref name="marikar">{{cite news|last=Marikar|first=Sheila|work=[[ABC News]]|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]|date=November 8, 2010|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/conan-leno-juiciest-quotes-war-late-night/story?id=12083560|accessdate=2010-11-08|title=What Really Went Down During the Conan vs. Leno Brawl: Juiciest Quotes From 'The War for Late Night'}}</ref>
{{quote box |width=25em | bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |align=right |halig=left | salign=right|quote="''The War for Late Night'' ... offers an exhaustive, eye-opening, how-could-he-possibly-know-that look at the late-night feud that ultimately was a muddled victory for Leno: He won back 'The Tonight Show,' but his ratings have fallen below O'Brien's."|source= —''[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]''<ref name="christopherlawrence">{{cite news|last=Lawrence|first=Christopher|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|url=http://www.lvrj.com/living/time-for-coco-to-relax-and-have-some-fun-106845453.html|accessdate=2010-11-08|title=Time for Coco to relax and have some fun|date=November 7, 2010}}</ref>}}
Frazier Moore of ''[[Associated Press]]'' wrote, "He plays this latest late-night conflagration right down the middle. He keeps the story moving almost cinematically, crosscutting from one personality to another, deftly and revealingly presenting different points of view."<ref name="jayvsconan" /> Writing for ''[[BusinessWeek]]'', Jim Windolf gave the book a rating of three stars out of a possible five, and commented, "Bill Carter has become the Bob Woodward of the 11:35 time slot."<ref name="windolf">{{cite news|last=Windolf|first=Jim|work=[[BusinessWeek]]|url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/10_46/b4203114875024.htm|accessdate=2010-11-08|date=November 4, 2010|title=Leno, Conan, Zucker, and 'The War for Late Night'}}</ref> Paula Duffy of ''HULIQ News'' described the book as "a juicy tell-all".<ref name="pauladuffy" /> Dylan Stableford of ''TheWrap'' called the book "a must-read" for fans of Conan O'Brien.<ref name="stableford" /> Jeff Simon of ''[[The Buffalo News]]'' called the book a "definitive history" of the 2010 Tonight Show conflict.<ref name="jeffsimon">{{cite news|last=Simon|first=Jeff|work=[[The Buffalo News]]|publisher=California Chronicle|title=Jeff Simon column|date=November 5, 2010}}</ref> Willa Paskin wrote for ''[[New York Magazine]]'' that Carter, "spoke with enough people involved in the situation to provide an account so detailed, it even includes re-created conversations and dialogue".<ref name="paskin" /> Neal Justin of ''[[Star Tribune]]'' commented on the author's neutrality in his writing style, "The next time network TV executives stumble into an ugly behind-the-scenes battle, they should consider hiring Bill Carter to negotiate. The veteran New York Times media reporter has a way of sharing juicy stories without painting anyone as a complete saint or sinner, a feat he pulls off again in his latest book, 'The War for Late Night: When Leno Went Early and Television Went Crazy'".<ref name="nealjustin">{{cite news|last=Justin|first=Neal|work=[[Star Tribune]]|publisher=[[Kansas City Star]]|title=New book goes behind the curtain at NBC's late-night fiasco|date=November 7, 2010}}</ref>
Nate Jones wrote for ''Time'' magazine, "There are no landmark surprises{{emdash}}Jay Leno comes off as affably opportunistic, Conan O'Brien as a tragic self-dramatist with a little bit of a martyrdom complex{{emdash}}but it's a worthwhile look at the procedural negotiations that led to last winter's messy divorce."<ref name="natejones" /> ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' said, "Bill Carter's book reveals explosive new details about the Jay Leno-O'Brien debacle."<ref name="thrjeffzucker" /> Kyle Anderson of ''[[MTV.com]]'' wrote, "the story takes an amazingly candid look at the conversations and arguments that went on behind the scenes. It even takes you to the moment when O'Brien decides that he has to walk away from 'The Tonight Show.'"<ref>{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=Kyle|work=[[MTV.com]]|title=Conan O'Brien: In Vanity Fair, On The Internet, Up In The Air|date=October 29, 2010|accessdate=2010-10-30|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2010/10/29/conan-obrien-vanity-fair/}}</ref> Paul Schwartzman of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote that it "is a great read and an example of narrative journalism's power when practiced by a reporter steeped in his subject matter."<ref name="storylab" /> Lynette Rice of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave Carter's book a rating of B-, and wrote, "In the end, Carter presents a pretty compelling argument that while the fourth-place network lost the public relations war, it probably won the late-night battle."<ref name="ricenov4" /> Speaking on his program ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'', host Howard Stern said of Carter's writing style, "It is just endlessly fascinating the way he paints this picture."<ref>{{cite news|last=Stern|first=Howard|authorlink=Howard Stern|work=[[The Howard Stern Show]]|date=November 4, 2010|publisher=[[Sirius XM Radio]]}}</ref>
==Film adaptation== On January 19, 2010, during O'Brien's last week of shows, guest [[Quentin Tarantino]] jokingly suggested that he direct a sequel to ''[[The Late Shift (film)|The Late Shift]]'', cast O'Brien as himself and make it a revenge movie in the style of his film ''[[Kill Bill]]'' with the title ''Late Shift 2: The Rolling Thunder of Revenge''.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2010/01/latenight-watch-the-revenge-of-conan-obrien.html | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | title=Show Tracker – Late-night Watch: The Revenge of Conan O'Brien|date=January 20, 2010|accessdate=2012-10-21|first=Mary |last=McNamara}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]|date=January 19, 2010|title=Season 1, Episode 142|author=[[Conan O'Brien]]; [[Quentin Tarantino]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/01/20/quentin-tarantino-conan-obrien/|title=Quentin Tarantino to direct Conan O'Brien in 'Late Shift 2: The Rolling Thunder of Revenge'|first=Mandi |last=Bierly|date=January 20, 2010|accessdate=2012-10-21|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]: PopWatch|publisher=Entertainment Weekly, Inc.; popwatch.ew.com}}</ref> ''[[The Toronto Star]]'' reported in February 2010 that a sequel to ''The Late Shift'' film was in planning stages.<ref>{{cite news| last =Salem | first = Rob | title = Why Tonight belongs to yesterday | work =[[The Toronto Star]] | publisher = Toronto Star Newspapers Limited | page =E01 | date =February 28, 2010 }}</ref> In the final episode of ''[[The Tonight Show with Conan O'Brien]]'', O'Brien said he wished that actress [[Tilda Swinton]] could portray him in a film version about ''The Tonight Show'' conflict.<ref>{{cite news | title =Conan O'Brien's next move | work = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | date = February 24, 2010 }}</ref> Swinton subsequently expressed interest in being cast as O'Brien in a sequel to ''The Late Shift''.<ref>{{cite journal | title =The Bullseye: Hits | journal = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | publisher =www.ew.com | date =January 29, 2010|issue=1088 | url =http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20340020,00.html | accessdate = 2010-10-04 }}</ref>
When asked in a June 2010 interview with ''[[Movieline]]'' whether there would be a film adaptation of the book, Carter said that plans were not serious at that point, and, "Not really. Nothing serious. Let's put it this way: There have always been people kicking it around because they think it's funny ... Letterman made a ... joke saying that [[Max von Sydow]] should play him. So, you know, people are just kicking it around like that."<ref name="juliemiller">{{cite news| last = Miller | first = Julie | title =Late Shift Author Bill Carter on ConanGate, Letterman’s Heirs and the Cannibalization of Late Night | work =[[Movieline]] | publisher =www.movieline.com | date = June 18, 2010 | url = http://www.movieline.com/2010/06/the-late-shift-author-bill-carter-on-conangate-lettermans-succesors-and-the-cannibalization-of-late.php | accessdate = 2010-10-04}}</ref> Actor [[Bob Balaban]], who portrayed NBC executive [[Warren Littlefield]] in ''The Late Shift'' said he would like to portray Jeff Zucker, and said [[Jason Alexander]] would also be a good choice to play Zucker.<ref>{{cite news| last = Gillette | first =Felix | title = Bob Balaban on Late Night | work = [[The New York Observer]] | date = January 27, 2010 }}</ref> [[Andy Richter]] jokingly told ''Movieline'' that he would want [[Justin Bieber]] to portray him in a film adaptation of the book.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Movieline]]|title=Andy Richter on Conan, the Masturbating Bear and the Possibility of a Jay Leno Superbowl Ad |page=2|last=Miller|first=Julie|date=November 8, 2010|accessdate=2010-11-08|url=http://www.movieline.com/2010/11/andy-richter-on-tbs-custody-of-the-masturbating-bear-and-the-possibility-of-a-superbowl-ad-with-jay.php?page=2}}</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT:War for Late Night}} [[Category:2010 non-fiction books]] [[Category:2010 Tonight Show conflict]] [[Category:Conan O'Brien]] [[Category:Jay Leno]] [[Category:Books about television]] [[Category:Books about California]] [[Category:Works about public relations]]

The '''usage''' of a [[language]] is the manner in which the written and spoken language is used, the "points of [[grammar]], [[syntax]], [[Style guide|style]], and the choice of words",<ref>[[Henry Watson Fowler|H. W. Fowler]]'s ''[[A Dictionary of Modern English Usage]]''</ref> and "the way in which a word or phrase is normally and correctly used". The usage of a language can mean the way people actually use the language, or [[Linguistic prescription|prescriptively]] the way one group feels that people ought to use it.<ref name=JB>{{Cite book|first=Jeremy|last=Butterfield|year=2008|title=Damp Squid: The English Language Laid Bare|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=9780199574094|pages=137–138}}</ref>
''[[The Chicago Manual of Style]]'' says "the great mass of linguistic issues that writers and editors wrestle with don't really concern grammar at all—they concern usage: the collective habits of a language's native speakers",<ref name=CMOS>{{cite book|author=University of Chicago|title=The Chicago Manual of Style|edition=16th|year=2010|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=9780199574094|pages=261–262}}</ref> and "the standards of good usage change, however slowly."<ref name=CMOS />
[[Dictionary|Dictionaries]] are not always accurate guides to "good usage". "Despite occasional usage notes, [[Lexicography|lexicographers]] generally disclaim any intent to guide writers and editors on the thorny points of English usage."<ref name=CMOS />
==History==
According to Jeremy Butterfield, "The first person we know of who made ''usage'' refer to language was [[Daniel Defoe]], at the end of the seventeenth century". Defoe proposed the creation of a [[Linguistic prescription|language society]] of 36 individuals who would set prescriptive language rules for the approximately six million English speakers.<ref name=JB />
